Deposit.definition: to place for safekeeping or as security [may the property with the court] ;esp

1.definition: the state of being deposited (as in an account) [holding the property on ] compare,

sub_terms.a: money deposited in a bank esp. to one's credit

demand deposit.definition: a bank deposit that can be withdrawn without prior notice

general deposit.definition: a deposit of money in a bank that is to the credit of the depositor thereby giving the depositor the right to money and creating a debtor-creditor relationship

special deposit.definition: a deposit that is made for a specific purpose, that is to be returned to the depositor, and that creates a bailment or trust

time deposit.definition: a bank deposit that can be withdrawn only after a set period of time or with prior notice

sub_terms.b: something given as security see also

time deposit.note: A deposit may be applied to a purchase price or may be considered partial payment.

sub_terms.a: the gratuitous transfer of possession of movable property to another for a limited time or specified purpose such that the depositary is liable to some extent for loss or damage to the property see alsocomparehiringandat

3.note: Like the common-law bailment, the civil law deposit requires either actual or constructive delivery.

necessary deposit.definition: a deposit compelled by a sudden emergency
necessary deposit.note: The Louisiana Civil Code deems the deposit of travelers' belongings with an innkeeper a necessary deposit.

voluntary deposit.definition: a deposit that is made by the mutual consent of the depositor and depositary

sub_terms.b: the movable property that is the object of a deposit [the depositary is bound to use the same diligence in preserving the that he uses in preserving his own property ""]

voluntary deposit.note: The consent required may be express or implied, and because of the requirements of consent, only persons with the capacity to contract can make a voluntary deposit.

4.definition: an act of depositing [upon the of the money in the escrow account]
